title: What's News: Business & Finance — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (October 15, 2019).

Johnson & Johnson, facing lawsuits from more than 100,000 plaintiffs over its product safety and marketing tactics, is battling many of the cases in court and losing a lot of them.

Lenders are charging record-high margins on credit cards, raising rates to help offset a hit to profitability from generous card-rewards programs.

Calhoun's appointment as Boeing's chairman puts a powerful behind-the-scenes figure in position to control the company's response to the 737 MAX crisis.

Authentic Brands is preparing a nearly $270 million bid for Barneys, with plans to license the brand to Saks Fifth Avenue.

The Nobel in economics was awarded to three economists for their pioneering approach to alleviating global poverty.

A House panel and Massachusetts are probing whether bot-generated social-media messages about e-cigarettes have been misleading consumers about safety.

Harley-Davidson has stopped production and deliveries of its first electric motorcycle after finding a problem related to the vehicle's charging equipment.

U.S. stocks inched lower in thin trading volumes ahead of third-quarter earnings season. The Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq all fell 0.1%.

California state officials lambasted PG&E's handling of last week's power shutdown.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 15, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
